document.text: The Miller Manual School, In Albemarle oonntT, on of the largest and most prosper ous institutions of tha kind in tbe South, baa recently accomplished on of the moat in teresting engineering feats that has been at tempted in Virginia for some time. This sobool, which was provided for In tko will of the late Samuel Miller, of Albemarle, is located near Greenwood depot, at the foot of tbe mountains in that county. Until re cently nil of the machinery used in the var ious shops la the institution was driven by earn engines, Mr. Vawter, the principal of tho sobool, ooncelved the idea of convert ing the old atream on the top of the moun tains Into a motive power to take the place of steam. A reservoir was constructed with a capacity o f 10,0 0,000 gallons, and Into this tbe stream was diverted. Tbe water Is brought down from tbo reservoir to the work shops In heavy Iron pipes. Tbe ele vation gives a fall of 250 teat, the highest fall used for manufacturing purposes, prob ably, in Virginia. The tnrbine wheel, which la propelled by this steam, furnishes motive power for generating eleotrlclty, which fur nishes the motive power for driving all the machinery.

document.text: The Miller Manual School, In Albemarle county, one of tbo largest and most prosper ous Institutions of the kind In the South, has recently accomplished one of the most in teresting snglnesrlng feats that has been at tempted In Virginia for some time. This sehool, which was provided for In the will of the late Samuel Miller, of Albemarle, Is located near Greenwood depot, at the foot of the mountains la that eounty. Until re cently til of tbs maehinery used in the var ious shops In the Institution was driven by steam anginas. Mr. Vawter, the principal of tho school, oonoelved tho idea of convert ing the old stream on tho top of tho moun tains Into a motive power to take ths place of steam. A reservoir was constructed with a capacity of 10,0 0,000 gallons, and into this tbs stream was diverted. The water Is brought down from tho reservoir to the work shops In heavy Iron pipes. The ele vation gives a fall of 250 feet, the highest fall used for manufacturing pnrposes, prob ably, in Virginia. The tnrbine wheel, wbloh is propelled by this steam, furnishes motive power for generstlng eleotriolty, which fur nishes the motive power for driving til the machinery.

document.text: The fourteenth annual confercncf of the Home Mission Society of tin Virginia Conference of the Methodise Episcopal Church South, adjourner at Lynchburg to meet next year a Central church, Portsmouth. The fol lowing officers were elected for tin ensuing year Mrs. W. J. Young, o1 Richmond, president Mrs. J. T. Mas tin, of Richmond, first vice-president her assistant to bp appointed Mrs L. B. Betty, of Richmond, second vice president Mrs. W. W. Lear, of Char iottesville, third vice-president Mrs M. N. Moorman, of Lyqchburg, cor responding secretary Mrs. R. I. Ow- ens, of Lynchburg, assistant Mrs. C V. Winfree, of Lynchburg, treasur er Mrs. H. E. Wall, of Farmville, re cording secretary Mrs. Minetrec Folkes, of Richmond, superintendent of literary and press work. J. Scott Moore, clerk of the Rock- oridge county trustee electoral school Doard, has been notified by Frank P. Brent, secretary of the state board of education, that Superintendent Southall has appointed G. Willis Ef- liuger, of Natural Bridge distret, acting superintendent of schools of Rockbridge county, vice Dr. A. Nash Johnston, deceased, until the edu cational board of Virginia can ap point a successor. Under a decision rendered by the state corporation commission the Dis mal Swamp Canal Company must pay taxes to tbe state just as other orporations do. The company was also fined ioo and costs for fail ure to make returns of its property for taxation. The company will prob ably take an appeal. Contract for fuel for use in the pub lic building at Norfolk, Va., for the next fiscal year has been awarded to the Norfolk Coal and Ice Company. The Norfolk and Southern Rail road, recently indicted by the Prin cess Anne county grand jury, was fined 300 for violating the Jim Crow car law, which provides for separate coaches fqr the races. This is the first conviction of its kind in the state. Jilted by the man to whom she came to Richmond from Norfolk to wed two months ago, Mrs. Lula B. Harper, formerly of Ohio, committed suicide sometime during the night by drowning herself in the reservoir lake near Richmond. Her body was found floating in three and a half feet of water, showing that she had lain down and determinedly kept her head un der the surface until death came. Het hat, pocketbook and comb were found on a bench near the edge of the water. At the concluding session of the Virginia Conferences of Charities and Corrections at Norfolk the following officers were elected C. E. Vawter, of Albemarle county, president Rev. C. S. Blackwell, Norfolk John M Higgins, Richmond Coi. S. W . Lane. Williamsburg, Prof. C. W. Kent. Charlottesville, and Thomas H. D Lafferty, Roanoke, vice-presidents. A heavy freight train crashed inte the rear ot a passenger train neat Penóla, on the Richmond, Fredericks burg and Potomac Railroad. The last oach was split open and Engineer Harry Perdue, of Richmond, was pain fully bruised. Failure to display sig nals is said to have been the cause. The stockholders of the Krise Bank- ing Company have decided to con vert that institution into a national bank, to he known as the Americar National Bank of Lynchburg, with a paid up capital of 150,000. J. Thompson Baird was nominated for the mayoralty of Portsmouth Bairds nomination is equivalent tc election. He has been mayor o Portsmouth for twenty-eight years Mayor Baird had two opponents, and it required a two-days contest to de cide the election. George Hansborough, a driver fo the Bèlle Pre Bottle Works of Alexan dria, was killed by an engine on th Southern Railroad at the crossing ir front of the office of the bottle works the horse he was driving being als killed. Mr. Hansborough was abou 35 years old, and is survived by i widow and two children. David Hook, a prisoner at the Win chester jail, escaped from a police man by a clever ruse. He apparenti

document.text: Roanoke.The amendments carried In Roanoke City by a vote of 6,097 to 411. Pulaski county gave majorities for tbe amendments ranging from 300 to 500. Bristol City gave majorities for the amendments averaging 544 for to 9 against. Tazewell epunty gave majorities Of 1,000 for the amend ments. Floyd county voted down tho rmo-idments. the vote ranging from 813 for to 823 against. Wythe county voted against tbe amendments by ma jorities ranging from 300 to 575. Roanoke county voted .for com pulsory education amendment 1,339 for to 362 against. Bond issue 1,341 for to 342 against. Amendment 32 carried 1,240 for to 310 against. Amendment 117 for 1,190 against 324. Amendment 133 for 1,320 against 332. Louisa.The tobacco growers of Louisa county organized at Louisa, and took steps to co-operate with sim ilar organizations in other counties of the sun-cured tobacco belt, with the view of advancing the price of tobac. co. The organization will be known as the Louisa branch of the Virginia Sun-cured Tobacco Growers Associa tion. The meeting was well attended by representative farmers from every section of the county and they seemed determined to fully co-operate with the mother organization and to make it cover the entire sun-cured belt. The main point at issues was the present low prices of sun-cured tobacco and the move to protect growers from the result of having tobacco sold for less than cost of production. A committee appointed to confer with similar committees from other counties in the sun-cured belt S. W Shelton, Thevilian C. V. Vawter, Louisa J. S. Wills, county agent, Louisa. Officers elected were as follows S. W. Shelton, president R. S. Dick inson, secretary-treasurer. Kenbridge.The Peoples Bank, a colored institution of this place, was entered by yeggmen, the vault door blown open by explosives and an at tempt made to force the safe. Nearby parties heard the noise and summoned assistance. A few shots fired into the building prevented the robbers from completing the job, they taking fright and running away. Bloodhounds placed upon the trail failed of results and it is thought that their escape was made in an automobile. In the absence of the cashier the full extent of the ioss is not known. Newport News.Thieves entered the plant of Langley Bottling Works here, removed a 1,600-pound safe, loaded it on an automobile truck and transported it to the outskirts of the city, where the strong box was blown open and about 500 in cash and valu able papers removed.

document.text: P ayne-W alton. One of the mosi interesting weddings of the early sum mer season was that, of- Miss Bessie Vawter Walton, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs E. A. Wal ton, of Appomattox, to Mr. Francis M. P,ayne, of Gladstone, in the presence of friends and relatives on the evening of June 2nd. The parlor in which thè ceremony took place had been prettily decorated for the occasion w ith ferns and other greens w ith the tw ilight effect produoed by lamps made a oharntlng setting for the as sembling of the bridal party. Promptly a t the hoar appoint ed, Miss A nna Smith of R. M. W. College, Lynchburg, touch ed the piano and pealed forth the inspiring strains of Mendel ssohns wedding m arch the bridal party entered. Rev. Mr. H. H. .Farris was best man Miss M artha Smith, Maid of Honor. Rev. Mr. Wingfield, pastor of the bride being the celebrant in plighting their troth. The bride was becoming ly attired in a faw n colored suit w ith hat and gloves to m atch. The groom wore the conventional black. Mrs. Payne is an accomplish ed young lady of sweet dispo sition endowed by nature with a bright mind and attractive personality. The groom is a native, of Nelson county with the exception of a few years in business spent in North Carol ina and since has been exten sively engaged in the lumber business. The popularity was attested by the many and use fui presents.

document.text: Jury At Christiansburg, Va., Require But One Ballot. Christiansburg, Va.  Charles E. Vawter, former professor at Virginia Polytechnic Institute, was acquitted by a Jury in the Montgomery County Circuit Court of the murder of Stock- ton Heth, Jr. The scene that followed the an nouncement of the verdict was an af fecting one. Deputy Clerk Trig Wal ters had not finished repeating the Jurys decision when Professor Vawter jumped from his chair and clasped his mother in his arms. The aged woman shouted, Oh, glory! Attorney R. L. Jordan, of Radford, one of Vawters counsel and the only lawyer in the room, with a fervent Thank God! sank into his chair and wept

document.text: John L. Lee, of Lynchburg, was re tained by members of the family of Stockton Heth, Jr., to assist in the prosecution of Professor Charles E, Vawter, of Blacksburg, charged with the murder of young Heth, who was mortally wounded on the morning of March 13 while a guest In the Vawter hpme. Mr. Lee has participated on one side or the other in most of the famous murder trials in Virginia dur ing the past twenty years.

document.text: Counsel For V. P. I. Profossor Issues Statement. Blacksburg, Va.Counsel for Prof. Charles E. Vawter, accused of killing Stockton Heth, Jr., issued a statement saying that after a thorough investi gation of the facts surrounding the tragedy, the evidence will disclose a betrayal of friendship and confidence reposed. This is the first statement from any member or representative of the Vaw ter family since young Heth was fatally shot in the Vawter home. Heth died at Roanoke and Professor Vaw ter gave new bond after waiving a preliminary hearing.

document.text: be done. Vawter, defending himself on tbe witness stand, wrote sin aid shame all over his life bistory of recent years Dr. Winston was conscript officer daring Confederate days and is ready to serve agan, thongh be ia no longer a young man. Mr. John Young is on the sick list. Mrs. J .  Martiu is rallying from a severe spell. Madames Irving, Walton and 8. W. Watkins attended the West Han over Presbyterial, which met last ween at Orange. Professor Royall, who tanght in the Dillwyn school the pas, session of seven months, is with ns for hi vacation and is boarding in tbe home of Mr. W. J. Hillsmu. The sweet girl graduates will toon appear before the footlights, but not in tbe usual costly dresses. Not jnst becoming, in these war times, when floor is 16 a barrel. Bat a small minority of the human family me wheat floor bread and we may do with much less. Those of ns who lived during Civil War days know all about substitutes and, feeding upon them, we didnt starve. A small boy parsed me this morn ing on his way to school dad tn a thin summer suit, wheu the air was crisp and coo. I sometimes won der of what stuff smalt biys are made, anyhow But they will soon be men and I hope better men than those who have gone beore them. I love to hear oid-tims farmyis disoacs farming. They differ, nt agree as to essentia. And the world will never look upon their like again.

document.text: B ent Creek. It almost seems that our village is lost to the literary world, but such is not the ca.e. Our people are so busy they dont have time to write. Mr. Wash McCormick has a very sick child, attended by Drs. Mundy, Vawter arid Cabell. A mothers anxiety is very great, but God al ways knows the best. Miss Nannie Woods school near ! led Oak closed on the 15 inst. We are glad to welcome her in onr midst again, but she speaks so favorably of the children up there we fear there is a tendency to draw her back. Miss Bettie Dixons school near Jowardsville closed on 18th inst. From the size of the bucket of candy sent from.our village sljjp left some  her scholars sweet

document.text: A negro who gave in bis name as Frank Vawter, and said to be from Walkeis Ford, was arrested on last Thursday night in Lynchburg for robbing a C.  O. freightcar. When hotly chased by two policemen, he jumped into the river. As he cant swim, he tried to wade across. On reaching water up to his month, he stopped, threw back his head, and , gazed at the sky till a policeman in
